content: The Act may be cited as the "Consumer Overdraft Protection Fair Practices Act" and includes restrictions on overdraft protection programs or services. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments define terms related to short-term extensions of credit under overdraft protection programs, including the definition of an overdraft protection fee as a fee imposed for covering checks or debits when there are insufficient funds in the account. The Act aims to regulate overdraft protection programs and services. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments define terms related to short-term extensions of credit under overdraft protection programs, including withdrawals from an account through an automated teller machine and electronic fund transfers initiated or authorized by the consumer. The Act also includes restrictions on overdraft protection programs or services. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments introduce restrictions on overdraft protection programs or services, stating that no overdraft protection fee can be charged without the consumer's written consent. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments require that any overdraft fee must be disclosed clearly in a written agreement with the consumer, including the amount of the fee, applicable disclosures, categories of transactions, and repayment time period. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments mandate clear disclosure of overdraft fees in written agreements with consumers, including fee amounts, transaction categories, repayment terms, and other required information. Overdraft protection fees are prohibited regardless of the fee amount in consumer transaction accounts. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments require transparent disclosure of overdraft fees in consumer agreements, prohibiting such fees regardless of the amount imposed by the institution for returned checks or debits. Institutions cannot misrepresent their willingness to cover all overdrafts in consumer accounts. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments mandate clear disclosure of overdraft fees in consumer agreements, prohibiting misrepresentation of overdraft protection programs in advertisements. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments require clear disclosure of overdraft fees and prohibit misrepresentation of overdraft protection programs in advertisements. Financial institutions are restricted from promoting transaction accounts as free if they include overdraft protection services with fees, encouraging use for short-term credit needs, or guaranteeing the honoring of all checks or debits presented. The Board will implement regulations to enforce these restrictions. The Board has the authority to restrict unfair or deceptive acts related to overdraft protection programs under the Truth in Lending Act Amendments. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments restrict advertising of overdraft protection programs and clarify finance charges. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act prohibits financial institutions from charging overdraft fees for ATM transactions with insufficient funds. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act prohibits financial institutions from charging overdraft fees for ATM transactions with insufficient funds unless the consumer has affirmatively requested such service and been provided with a notice of the overdraft protection fee before completing the transaction. Financial institutions must disclose only the actual dollar balance in the consumer's account at the time of the request, excluding any additional credit or overdraft protection.
